description: Late Middle English, from Anglo-Norman cotage and Medieval Latin cotagium, from Old Northern French cot, cote (“hut, cottage”) + -age (“surrounding property”), from Proto-Germanic *kutan, *kuta- (“shed”), probably of non-Indo-European origin, possibly borrowed from Uralic; compare Finnish kota (“hut, house”) and Hungarian ház (“house”), both from Proto-Finno-Ugric/Proto-Uralic *kota.  However, also compare Dutch and English hut.
Old Northern French cote is probably from Old Norse kot (“hut”), cognate of Old English cot of same Proto-Germanic origin.
Slang sense “public toilet” from 19th century, due to resemblance.

entries.meaning: A seasonal home of any size or stature, a recreational home or a home in a remote location.
examples: Most cottages in the area were larger and more elaborate than my home.

entries.meaning: (Polari) A meeting place for homosexual men.
examples: Synonyms: gingerbread office, tea room, tearoom, teahouse, (US) tea house

verbs.description: cottage (third-person singular simple present cottages, present participle cottaging, simple past and past participle cottaged)

entries.meaning: To stay at a seasonal home, to go cottaging.
(intransitive, Polari, of men) To have homosexual sex in a public lavatory; to practice cottaging.
